message.content: This question requires knowledge about the hardness and abrasiveness of different materials. Beach sand is typically made up of tiny particles of rock and minerals, which can scratch and damage the surface of a windshield. Option (B) is incorrect because non-abrasive sponges are not rough enough to scratch a windshield. Option (C) is incorrect because rubber is not abrasive and would not cause scratches. Option (D) is incorrect because prophylactics (condoms) are made of latex or other non-abrasive materials that would not scratch a windshield.

Option (A) is correct because beach sand contains small particles that can scratch the surface of a windshield. Option (B) is incorrect because non-abrasive sponges are designed to be gentle and not scratch surfaces. Option (C) is incorrect because rubber standoffs are soft and would not scratch a windshield. Option (D) is incorrect because prophylactics, or condoms, are made of latex or other materials that are not abrasive and would not scratch a windshield.

This question asks about what can easily scratch a windshield. To answer this question, we need some knowledge about the properties of different materials. Option (A) states that beach sand can easily scratch a windshield. This is because sand contains small, hard particles that can create tiny scratches on the surface of the windshield when rubbed against it. Option (B) is incorrect because non-abrasive sponges are specifically designed to be gentle on surfaces and not scratch them. Option (C) is also incorrect because rubber standoffs would not have the hardness required to scratch a windshield. Option (D) is incorrect because prophylactics (condoms) are made of a soft material and do not have the hardness required to scratch a windshield.
